Arabic Manuscripts from West Africa--The ‘Umar Falke Collection

A poem providing instruction in the proper use of the siwāk--a teeth cleaning stick widely used throughout the Muslim world. The use of the siwāk in Muslim societies is regulated by precise rules, which the poem enumerates, along with information about the siwāk's health benefits.

The images on this web site are from material in the collections of the Melville J. Herskovits Library of African Studies at Northwestern University Libraries, are provided for use by its students, faculty and staff, and by other researchers visiting this site, for research consultation and scholarly purposes only. Further distribution and/or any commercial use of the images from this site is not permitted.

Homepage at Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections

This rare collection of manuscripts dates back to the 19th and 20th centuries and come from mainly northern Nigeria (Kano in particular) but also includes items from Ghana, Senegal and Mali. Mostly handwritten in Arabic and Ajami scripts, these manuscripts cover a wide range of subjects from Arabic grammar, history, theology, law and astronomy to name a few, with particular strength in Tijâniyya Sufi order and Hausa poetry.   Comprised of 5,000 items, the manuscripts are split across four separate collections and serve as an excellent example of West African literacy in Arabic:  The 'Umar Falke Collection, The John Paden Collection, The John Hunwick Collection, The University of Ghana Collection

*Translated by Said Bousbina*

In the name of God, the Compassionate, the Merciful. May God pour out His prayer and salvation on our master, Muḥammad, on his family and on his companions.

- O you who question me about the status of the *siwāk*[^1]
  - and what *fiqh*[^2] has decided on this subject!

- I answer: May God guide you towards the straight path, O you who ask the best of questions!
  - The question you asked is among the essential points of Religion.

- Here is a peremptory response. If you retain it,
  - you will be, O young man!, sage and insightful.

- On the subject \[of *siwāk*\] there are several *ḥadīths*[^3] of Aḥmad,
  - transmitted in a sure manner, by men of confidence according to other men of confidence.

- The Messenger of God had established his *siwāk* as a precept,
  - and it became, for us, a rule of conduct through effort.

- Still, it is necessary, from time to time, to stress this point.
  - Thus, I will let you know all its merits, one by one.

- Whether during ablutions, prayer, prostration, recitation \[of the Qurʾan\],
  - or when the teeth turn yellow, quickly use the *siwāk*.

- Just as when you are alone, before sleeping, after waking up,
  - during a long silence or if you have bad breath.

- After having eaten or if you enter a home,
  - use the *siwāk*, you will thus respect the Tradition \[of the Prophet\].

- Privilege prayer after having used the *siwāk*,
  - as it is mentioned in the *ḥadīth* of the Chosen one, the Virtuous.

- The use of the *siwāk* is disapproved only for he who fasts,
  - and that only until the afternoon, according to certain *imāms*.[^4]

- Do not forget to pronounce "*bismillāh*"[^5] when you begin to use the *siwāk*.
  - The rest is done without invocation.

- It is recommended to use the *siwāk* across the width of the tongue,
  - \[and\] its length, as stipulated in various texts and commentaries.

- Any soft *siwāk* stick, even of poor quality,
  - can be used, without a doubt.

- However, it is preferable to use arak wood[^6] because
  - this was the *siwāk* used by the Messenger of God, the guide of all creatures.

- You cannot use a finger in place of the *siwāk*
  - when you have one with you. Such is the order of the community.

- The length of your *siwāk* should be the equivalent of one *shibr.*[^7] Do not take it any longer,
  - for any part which exceeds \[the *shibr*\], Satan occupies it.

- Grasp your *siwāk* with your right hand, putting
  - your fingers on top of it, according to the Tradition \[of the Prophet\],


[^1]: The *siwāk* is a twig used to clean teeth, typically taken from the *Salvadora persica* tree, which has antibacterial properties. These natural toothbrushes have been used throughout the Arabo-Muslim world since antiquity.

[^2]: Although often translated as "Islamic jurisprudence," *fiqh* originally meant "understanding, knowledge, intelligence."

[^3]: *Ḥadīth*: An action or saying of the Prophet Muḥammad, constituting a source of Islamic law. "Aḥmad" is an alternative name for the Prophet Muḥammad.

[^4]: *Imām*: an Islamic leadership position, often the prayer leader in a mosque.

[^5]: *Bismillāh al-raḥmān al-raḥīm*: In the name of God, the Most Righteous, the Most Merciful. One of the most important phrases for Muslims, who speak it when initiating many activities and during daily prayer.

[^6]: *Salvadora persica*, known as the arak tree, is a small evergreen found in the Middle East, Africa, and South Asia.

[^7]: *Shibr*: the span of a hand, between the thumb and little finger.

بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم صلى الله على سيدنا محمد وآله وصحبه وسلم تسليما  

- أيا سائلاً لي عن سِوَاكٍ وحُكْمِهِ  
  - وما فيه من أحكامِ فِقْهٍ وحِكْمَةِ
- وقلتُ  هداك اللهُ يا خيرَ سائلٍ
  - سألت سؤالاً من مُهمّاتِ مِلَّةِ  
- فهاك جوابا شافيا إن حفظته  
  - تكنْ يا فتى من أهلِ علمٍ وفطنةِ
- ففي فضله جاءتْ أحاديثُ أحمدٍ  
  - رواها ثِقاتٌ عن ثِقاتٍ بصحةِ 
- وكان رسولُ الله فرضًا سواكُه
  - وصار علينا سُنّةً لِلْمشقّةِ
- ولكنه في بعضِ حالٍ مُؤكدٌ
  - وصار علينا سُنّةً لِلْمشقّةِ
- وُضوءٌ صلاةٌ سجدةٌ وقراءةٌ
  - وعند اصفرارِ السِّنِّ فَاسْتك بِسرعةِ
- ومنها طوافٌ ثم نومٌ ويَقْظَةٌ
  - وطولُ سكوتٍ أو تغيُّرُ نَكْهةِ
- ومن بعد أكلٍ أو دخولِك منزلاً
  - إذا استَكْتَ بالمِسواكِ جئت بسُنَّةِ
- وكلُّ صلاةٍ بالسِّواكِ فَفَضْلُها
  - كما في حديث المصطفى لِلْمَزِيّةِ
- ولا تَكْرِهِ المسواكَ إلا لِصائمٍ
  - عُقَيْب زوالٍ عند بعض الْأَئِمةِ
- ولا تنسَ بسمِ الله عند ابْتدائهِ
  - وما جاء في المِسواك في غير دَعوةِ
- ويُندب أن يَستاك عِرْضًا وفي اللّسَا
  - نِ طولًا كذا المنصوصُ في شرْحِ عُمْدَةِ
- وكلُّ قضيبٍ ليّنٌ ذي خُشُونَةٍ
  - به يحصُل السِّواكُ من غيْر مِرْيِةِ
- ولكنه الأَوْلَى أراكٌ لأنّهُ
  - سواكُ رسولِ الله هادي البَريَّةِ
- ولا يُجزئُ السواك يوما بِأصبعٍ
  - بوُجْدانِ مِسْواكٍ كذا حُكْمُ خِرْقةِ
- وطولُ سواكٍ قَدْرُ شِبْرٍ ولا تَزِدْ
  - فما زاد للشيطانِ موْضِعُ جَلْسَةِ
- وخذ بيدك اليُمنى سِواكَكَ جاعلاً
  - أصابعَها فوق السِّواكِ لِسُنَّةِ

- except the little finger, O my friend!, put it underneath
  - and the thumb also underneath the *siwāk*, according to the Tradition \[of the Prophet\].

- Satan uses his left hand to hold the *siwāk*. His disciples
  - and his actions are contrary to Divine Law.

- Do not grab the *siwāk* in your hand.
  - It risks being contaminated by germs that cause jaundice.[^8]

- When using the *siwāk*, put it to the right of your teeth.
   - To benefit from *siwāk*, one must express the intention[^9] deep within oneself to use it.

- Be careful not to use the *siwāk* when you defecate,
  - or when urinating or lying completely on your back.

- \[Using the *siwāk*\] attracts the satisfaction of the Merciful and the love of the angels,
  - it allows you to curse Satan and alleviate bitterness.[^10]

- It makes the eyes shine, stops the phlegm[^11]
  - And fights against aging and provides vigor.

- Swallowing saliva during the first use of the *siwāk* of the day
  - protects you against leprosy, and even against all diseases.

- On the other hand, do not swallow the saliva afterwards, O young man!
  - for fear of having bad thoughts and troubled ideas.

- Never use both ends of the *siwāk*.
  - Listen to my advice, if you are a reasonable man!

- When we do not clean the *siwāk* after use,
  - it is licked by Satan the banished, the cursed.

- Sucking the *siwāk* while using it is frowned upon
  - because it causes serious damage to the eyes.

- Honest people have the habit of burying their spit
  - underground when they use the *siwāk*. They are wise people.

- Accustom your young child to using the *siwāk*, O my brother!
  - In this way his offspring will become used to its benefits.

- The end, thanks to God!, of my poem
  - on the status of the *siwāk* and what has been said about it.

- I end my poem with a prayer
  - for the best of God\'s creatures, the intercessor of the *imāms* \[with God\],

- Muḥammad, the Chosen One, the descendant of Hāshim,[^12]
  - And for his family, his companions, his wives and his relatives.

Thanks be to God, Lord of the Universe  
Prayer and salvation  
For he who has the power to intercede with God

*k.y.k.t.j.*    *k.y.k.t.j.*[^13] 


[^8]: Arabic: *al-ṣufra*.

[^9]: Arabic: *al-niyya*.

[^10]: Arabic: *al-mirra*, meaning gall, bile.

[^11]: Arabic: *balgham.* The use of this term--derived from the Ancient Greek, *phlégma*--along with *al-mirra* (bile) and *al-sufra* (jaundice)--indicates the influence of Ancient Greek and Roman medicine, particularly the theory of the four humors (blood, phlegm, yellow bile, and black bile) on Islamic medicine. See Ismail H. Abdalla, *Islam, Medicine, and Practitioners in Northern Nigeria* (Lewiston: Edwin Mellen Press, 1997), 57-9. For another text in *Maktaba* that references humoral theory, see [*Epidemic*](https://nulib-ds.github.io/maktaba/works/epidemic-al-ajj-umar-of-kete-krachi-d-1934) and its accompanying essay, ["A Poetic Approach to Public Health."](https://nulib-ds.github.io/maktaba/essays/poetic-approach-to-public-health)

[^12]: Hāshim b. ʿAbd Manāf (c. 464-497) was the great-grandfather of the Prophet Muḥammad and the progenitor of the Banū Hāshim clan of the Quraysh tribe in Mecca.

[^13]: The word كيكتج (*kaykataj*) written on both sides of the page is an interesting feature appearing in some Islamic manuscripts. It refers to the *Ranunculus asiaticus* (Persian buttercup)--a poisonous plant known to repel the insects that can gnaw at manuscript paper and bindings. Writing "*kaykataj*" on the manuscript was believed to have a repellent effect. There are several variations of this word. *Kaykataj* is used in the western Africa region, while in other parts of the Islamic world, it is "*kabīkaj*," "*kaykaj*," or "*kabkaj*." See Dorrit Van Dalen, "Damage and Protection," Lesson 7, Mouse&Manuscript (Leiden University), accessed October 17, 2024, [https://mouse.digitalscholarship.nl/lessons/damage-and-protection](https://mouse.digitalscholarship.nl/lessons/damage-and-protection); and "Kabīkaj," in Adam Gacek, *Arabic Manuscripts: A Vademecum for Readers* (Leiden: Brill, 2009), 137-38.

- سوى خِنصرٍ يا صاحي فاجْعله تحتهُ
  - وإبليسُ باليسرى يَسُوكُ وجُنْدُه 
- ولا تأخذِ المسواكَ ضَمًّا بقَبْضَةٍ 
  - لإِيراثِهِ البَاسُورَ  جَالبَ صُفْرَةِ
- إذا اسْتَكْتَ فاجْعلْ جانبَ السِّنِّ أيْمَنًا 
  - ولا تحملِ المسواكَ إلا بِنِيَّةِ
- وإياك أن تستاك في غائطٍ
  - وبولٍ ومستلقٍ  على ظهرِ فَقْرةِ
- ومنها رضا الرحمن معْ حُبِّ ملاك
  - ومَسْخَطِ شيطانٍ وإطفاء مِرّةِ
- ويجلو عيونا ثم يقطع بلْغما 
  - ويعطي لضُعْف السِّنِّ غايةَ قوةِ
- وبلعُك ريقًا أولًا من تَسوُّكٍ 
  - أمانُ جذام بل شفا كلِّ عِلَّةِ
- ومن بعده لا تبلع الريق يا فتى 
  - مخافة وسْواسٍ مشوّشِ فكرةِ
- ومن طرفيه لا تكن قطُّ عاصِلاً
  - وإن كنت ذا عقل قبلت وصيتي
- إذا استاك إنسانٌ وأهمل غُسْله 
  - فيلعقه  الشيطان مطرودُ لَعنةِ
- ويكره للمستاك مصُّ سواكه 
  - ففي مصّه للعيْن أقوى مضرّةِ
- ومن عادة الأبرار دفنُ بُصاقهم 
  - بِتُرْبٍ إذا استاكوا وهمْ أهلُ مكةِ
- وعوِّدْ بمسواكٍ صبيّك يا أخي 
  - ليعتاد بالخير في حال نشأةِ
- وتمت بتوفيق الإله قصيدتي 
  - وما في سواكٍ من كلامٍ وحكمةِ
- ولكنني نظمي ختمت مصليا 
  - وما في سواكٍ من كلامٍ وحكمةِ
- ولكنني نظمي ختمت مصليا
  - على خير خلق الله شافعُ أمةِ
- محمدٍ المختارِ من نسلِ هاشم 
  - وآلٍ وصحبٍ ثم زوجٍ وعِترةِ

 الحمد لله رب العالمين. الصلاة والسلام على من وجبت له الشفاعة.
 كيكتج
